pain_points_original.title: Compliance with Privacy & Security Standards
pain_points_original.description: The DPC must ensure strict adherence to "Applicable ICT, Security and Cyber policies" and "South Australian Information Privacy Principles (IPPs)". The critical problem is the risk of deploying AI that violates these mandates, requiring robust "measures taken to protect sensitive information".

pain_points_original.title: Secure Integration of Third-Party LLMs
pain_points_original.description: The DPC faces specific risks regarding "third-party offerings, particularly large language models (LLMs)". They need to solve how to utilize these powerful tools while ensuring the "security and safeguarding of government data," guided by their internal "Guideline-13.1-Use-of-Large-Language-Model".

pain_points_original.title: Interoperability with Legacy Infrastructure
pain_points_original.description: A major technical hurdle is the "integration needs with any existing systems and platforms". The DPC needs to determine the "maturity, scalability, and adaptability" of new AI solutions to ensure they function seamlessly within the established government IT environment without creating silos.

pain_points_original.title: Improving Service Delivery Efficiency
pain_points_original.description: The DPC aims to solve operational inefficiencies and "increase public satisfaction". They require technologies that "enhance efficiency, decision-making, and service delivery" to achieve "better community outcomes," indicating current processes are likely too slow or resource-intensive.

pain_points_original.title: Financial Planning for AI Adoption
pain_points_original.description: The DPC lacks visibility into the cost of emerging AI tech, making budgeting difficult. They need to obtain "indicative costing models and pricing structures" to solve the problem of inaccurate "future procurement planning and budget allocation" for 2026 and beyond.

pain_points_original.title: Mitigating Deployment Risk via Proven Use Cases
pain_points_original.description: To avoid the risk of failed implementations, the DPC needs to validate "evidence of the tool's technical capability... in environment similar to DPC". They need to learn from "vendors' experiences in deploying AI solutions within similar sectors" to ensure reliability before commitment.
